results.title: Une Femme Douce = a Gentle Creature
results.brief_description:
A young woman marries a pawnbroker but finds she cannot adapt her life to his. She toys with murdering him, but kills herself instead. With the introduction of colour in his films, beginning with ‘Une femme douce’, Bresson’s vision darkened, his growing pessimism disclosed in an increasingly voluptuous rendering of the world. (One might say sobriety invites intoxication.) The flatness of Bresson’s compositions and his emphasis on dedramatization places Bresson in the tradition of modernism, yet his universe often seems archaic.” Reference: James Quandt. The poetry of precision: the films of Robert Bresson. Cinematheque Ontario. Online. http://www.bell.ca/filmfest/cinematheque/bresson.htm. Further reading: Film Comment. ‘Special Bresson’. May-June and July 1999

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Robert Bresson ; writer, Robert Bresson ; photography, Ghislain Cloquet ; music, W. A. Mozart, Henry Purcell, Jean Wiener ; art direction, Pierre Charbonnier.
Cast: Dominique Sanda, Guy Frangin, Jane Lobre, Claude Ollier, Dorothee Blank.

results.title: India Song
results.brief_description:
In the 1930s, Anne-Marie Stratter lives in Calcutta with her husband, the French Ambassador. During a reception at the Embassy, Anne-Marie dances with her lover, Michael Richardson, unaware of her husband’s glances. Anne-Marie is equally unaware of the passion in the vice-consul’s eyes. The vice-consul declares is passion to Anne-Marie. She rebuffs him. The vice-consul runs off and a heartrending cry tears the stillness of the night. Further viweing: In ‘Son nom de Venise dans Calcutta desert’(1976), Marguerite Duras re-uses the same soundtrack, this time accompanied with images of the Embassy, now deserted, where the action of ‘India Song’ took place. The closing sequence of ‘Son nom de Venise dans Calcutta desert’ is used as the opening sequence for ‘India Song’.

Credits: Producer, Stephane Tchalgadjieff ; director, Marguerite Duras ; writer, Marguerite Duras ; photography, Bruno Nuytten ; music, Ludwig van Beethoven, Carlos d’Alessio.
Cast: Delphine Seyrig, Michel Lonsdale, Claude Mann, Mathieu Carriere, Didier Flamand, Vernon Dobtcheff.

results.title: Man of marble = Czlowiek z marmuru
results.creator_credit: Andrzej Wajda, Zespol Filmowy 'X' and Film Polski
results.brief_description: Lauded a national hero in the 1950s due to his skills at his trade, Mateusz Birkut has fallen into the shadows. In making a film of the bricklayer’s life, documentary director Krystyna Janda discovers that he used his fame to become involved in politics - resulting in the government wiping out all traces of his accomplishments. Excised by the Polish censors when first released, ‘Man of marble’ uses reconstructions of old black and white newsreels and matches the stylistic tenets of the documentary genre. (Awards: Winner of the FIPRESCI award, Cannes Film Festival, 1978). In Polish with English subtitles.

results.title: Le Desordre a Vingt Ans = Disorder Is Twenty Years Old
results.brief_description:
In this documentary, Jacques Baratier compares life in the St Germain des Pres area of Paris in the the post WWII years and 20 years later in the Sixties (pre May 68). Rare documents and seldom seen footage of personalities, “overexposed films shot in obscure places” such as ‘Le Tabou’ recreate the ambiance of the great existentialist era. The interviewees recall the social changes that led to the movement. They include: Boris Vian, Alain Vian, Roger Blin, Juliette Greco, Raymond Queneau, Jean Cau, Simone de Beauvoir, Jean-Paul Sartre, Sophie Desmarets, Jean Cocteau, Roger Pierre, Arthur Adamov, Cesar, Anne-Marie Cazalis, Michel de Re, Roger Vadim, Annabel, Gabriel Pomerand, Sydney Bechet, Claude Luter etc… This film is followed by ‘Voila l’ordre’.

Credits: Director, Jacques Baratier.

results.title: Benito Cereno
results.brief_description:
In 1799, the Santo Domingo is sailing to Peru, when a slave mutiny erupts on board. Only seven crew members survive, including the Captain, Benito Cereno. The leader of the mutiny, Atimbo, wants to sail back to Africa. When the ship encounters troubles, an American vessel comes to the rescue. Cereno explains that his crew has taken ill with scurvy, including the human cargo imported from Africa. The slaves are down to only a few healthy men and Cereno is awaiting the right

Credits: Director, Serge Roullet ; writer, Serge Roullet ; photography, Ricardo Arronovitch.
Cast: Ruy Guerra, Georges Selmark, Temour Diop, Jacques Mercier, John Turner, Serge Roullet, Philippe Noury.

results.title: Le Vieil Homme et L' Enfant = the Old Man and the Boy
results.brief_description:
During the nazi occupation of Paris, an irrepressible eight-year old jewish boy, Claude, is sent to stay with an elderly couple in the country. Since Pepe, the old man, is a rabid anti-semite, the boy is instructed to conceal his origins. Once there, Claude and Pepe forge a close relationship - beautifully realized in the playing - in which the boy is amused by the old man’s bigoted outburst and delights in provoking him, while Pepe comes to dote on the child. Berri’s film is a reconstruction of his own childhood experience and he describes it as a ‘love affair between a Jew and an anti-Semite’. Awards: Berlin Film Festival (1967): Best Actor for Michel Simon.

Credits: Director, Claude Berri ; writers, Gerard Brach, Claude Berri ; photography, Jean Penzer ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Michel Simon, Alain Cohen, Charles Denner, Luce Fabiole, Roger Carel, Paul Preboist, Zorica Lozice.

results.title: The Last seduction
results.creator_credit: John Dahl, Jonathan Shestack and ITC Entertainment Group
results.brief_description: An updated film noir centering around Bridget Gregory, a beautiful, intelligent and ambitious femme fatal. After convincing her doctor husband to pull off a $700,000 cocaine deal, Bridget takes of with the money and hides out in a small town, where she meets Mike. She is tracked down by a private investigator hired by her husband. As the two start to close in on Bridget, she involves Mike in an elaborate scheme to keep the money and get rid of her husband. Cast includes: Linda Fiorentino, Peter Berg, Bill Pullman, J.T. Walsh and Bill Nunn. (Awards: New York)

results.title: Journal D'une Femme de Chambre = Diary of a Chambermaid (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Michel Safra, Serge Silberman and Luis Bunuel
results.brief_description:
Celestine takes up a position as chambermaid in a middle-class family and becomes the catalyst that reveals their sexual, religious and social repressions. The film, foot fetishism and all, is pure Bunuel, a sharp social satire in which the sexy, cruel and cool Jeanne Moreau is wonderful. Jean Renoir directed a version of ‘Le journal d’une femme de chambre’ in 1934.

Credits: Producers, Serge Silberman, Michel Safra; director, Luis Bunuel ; writers, Luis Bunuel, Jean-Claude Carriere ; photography, Roger Fellous ; art direction, Georges Wakhevitch.
Cast: Jeanne Moreau, Michel Piccoli, Francoise Lugagne, Georges Geret, Jean Geret, Daniel Ivernel, Gilberte Geniat, Muni, Dominique Sauvage, Jean-Claude Carriere, Jean Ozenne, Andree Tainsy.

results.title: Nathalie Granger
results.brief_description:
With little or no embellishment, film-maker Marguerite Duras offers a simple, often wordless chronicle of a woman’s day. She and her friend are seen doing yard work, talking about their families and receiving the occasional visitor. The brightest spot in the day is when a washing machine salesman comes to call.

Credits: Producer, Luc Moullet ; director, Marguerite Duras ; writer, Marguerite Duras ; photography, Ghislain Cloquet ; music, Marguerite Duras ; editor, Nicole Lubtchansky ; other crew, Benoit Jacquot, Bruno Nuytten, Michel Vionnet.
Cast: Jeanne Moreau, Lucia Bose, Gerard Depardieu, Valerie Mascolo, Dionys Mascolo, Luce Garcia-Ville.
